Title: The amygdaloid complex in monkey studied by reconstructional methods

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation:
"In 1938 however, a study of the human amygdala by Brockhaus appeared which uses an entirely different terminology and subdivides each of the main nuclei. Lauer ('45) has studied the amygdaloid complex of the monkey, but has not made extensive subdivisions in the light of the findings of Brockhaus.
In order to determine how the two interpretations compared it was decided to subdivide the amygdala of the monkey as objectively as possible, to make a graphic reconstruction of the patterns obtained and then to compare the interpretations of the two schools with the reconstruction." (p. 508)

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Basal amygdaloid nucleus. …The pars lateralis (API, figs. 1-6) can be divided into magnocellular, mediocellular and parvocellular parts. The magnocellular part (mac, figs. 2-6) occupies a dorsal position. This part has two distinct subdivisions: the ventral subdivision (macv, fig. 4) is continuus with the remaining portion of the pars lateralis of the basal nucleus and presents a dorsomedial prolongation (macdm, fig. 4). The dorsal subdivision forms an independent mass of cells (macdl, fig. 4) dorsal to the lateral nucleus. …Ventrally, the mediocellular (mec, fig. 2-6) portion is formed by paler, smaller and sparser cells. The parvocellular portion (pc, figs. 2-6) is situated basally in the lateral part of the basal nucleus and between the mediocellular and the supragranular portions." (pp. 511, 514)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Area API is the lateral part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus and area APV the medial part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The lateral amygdaloid nucleus has been recognized as one of the main divisions of the amygdala. Histologically, however, the lateral nucleus of the monkey can be shown to include 5 distinct portions: limitans, gracilicellularis, magnocellularis, mediocellularis and parvocellularis. Laterally, the lateral amygaloid nucleus is bounded by the external capsule. In its rostral half the dorsolateral part of the lateral nucleus is broken into by fiber bundles of the stria terminalis passing forward to the anterior commissure. This portion of the lateral nucleus has a special aspect and forms the limitans portion (li, figs. 2-5). …The gracilicellularis (gc, figs. 2-3) forms a dorsomedial prolongation situated in the anterior half of the lateral nucleus, between the magnocellularis of the basal nucleus ventrally, the oralis portion of the amygdaloid anterior area dorsally and the accessory basal nucleus medially. …The remaining chief nuclear mass of the lateral nucleus is divisible into a dorsal magnocellular portion (mac, figs. 2-6) situated ventral to the limitans portion and distinguishable from the other parts of the lateral nucleus by the denser arrangements of its neurons. There is also an intermediate mediocellular portion (med, figs. 2-6) and a ventral parvocellular portion (pc, figs. 2-5)." (p. 508, 511)

"(APM, figs 2-6). The accessory basal nucleus or amygdaleum profundum mediale of Brockhaus has an oval shape. The cephalic pole lies in intimate relation with the cortical amygdaloid nucleus. Its caudal tip appears caudal to the posterior poles of the basal and lateral nuclei. Previous writers have made a subdivision of the accessory basal nucleus into medial and lateral portions. In the present reconstructive study and according to the cellular disposition 4 portions can be recognized in the accessory basal nucleus of the monkey: partes magnocellularis, mediocellularis, densocellularis and mixtocellularis. A secondary subdivision of the magnocellular portion into a lateral and medial part is evident. The pars magnocellularis lateralis (macl, figs. 4-6) is located laterodorsal within the accessory basal nucleus laterally, contains the largest neurons of this nucleus, and appears homogeneous and deeply stained. The pars magnocellularis medialis (macm, figs. 2-6) has a medial situation within the accessory nucleus.It contains an intermingling of small and large neurons. These nuclei are in relation with the pars magnocellularis lateralis, the mediocellularis and the densocellularis. The mediocellular portion (mec, figs. 2-6) is located between both magnocellular portions and is very similar histologically to the medial portion but can be recognized because its cellular density is poorer. Thepars mixtocellularis (mic, figs. 4-6) occupies a ventrocaudal situation in the accessory nucleus containing small and medium sized cells, with a preponderance of granular neurons.The densocellular portion (dc, figs. 4-5) is a small rounded mass that appears in the accessory nucleus between the medial magnocellular and the mediocellular portions, in the medial third of the longitudinal axis of this nucleus." (p. 518)

"The pars medialis (APV, figs. 1-6) is situated ventromedial to the pars lateralis. It can be divided into pyramidal, granular, supragranular, and glomerular portions. The pyramidal portion (py, figs. 2-6) is situated between the corticoamygdaloid transition area medially, the pars lateralis of the basal nucleus laterally, and the accessory basal nucleus dorsally. It is narrow in its rostral pole and wider in the caudal tip. It contains small and middle sized neurons and a few pyramidal cells. The granularis (gr, figs. 2-5) forms a narrow portion situated between the pyramidalis and the supragranularis. It contains intermingled small granular and medium sized cells. Both granularis and pyramidalis form the deep portion of the medial part of the basal nucleus of other authors. The supragranularis (sgr, fig. 2-6) corresponds to the superficial part of Lauer and consists of a gray band which merges laterally with the lateral nucleus and medially with the cortico-amygdaloid transition area or with the pyriform cortex. It is formed of small, deeply stained granular cells. The glomerular portion forms several independent small masses (gl, fig. 6) and a large mass situated between the lateral nucleus and the ventricle (gl, fig. 4)." (pp. 514, 518)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Area API is the lateral part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus and area APV the medial part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "The cortical nucleus described by Lauer ('45; monkey) and Crosby and Humphrey ('41; man) corresponds to the amygdaleum superficiale and the periamygdaleum of Brockhaus' nomenclature. In this work the cortical amygdaloid nucleus has been studied with the criteria of the German writer in mind and the following considerations and secondary subdivisions have been made: superficially, the periamygdaleum is composed of portions of the second cortical layer and contains small and very numerous deeply stained pyramidal neurons. These layers do not present a continuity as in the cortex and they can be divided into (1) an oral part with dorsal (pAid, figs. 1-2) and ventral (pAov, figs. 1-2) divisions; (2) and intermediate part with dorsal (pAd, figs. 3-5) intermediate (pAi, figs. 3-5) and ventral (pAcv, fig. 6) divisions. The amygdaleum superficiale (Asf, figs. 1-6) is the representation of other cortical layer in the amygdala, but it cannot be subdivided, forming instead a heteregeneous portion with no specific cellular composition. Morphologically, this portion forms a large layer medial to the basolateral group, and has two poles (caudal and oral) and intermediate portion. Dorsal and ventral parts are distinguishable in each of these subdivisions. All these structures are shown in the accompanying reconstruction and together form the cortical nucleus of previous writers." (p. 520)

"The cortical nucleus described by Lauer ('45; monkey) and Crosby and Humphrey ('41; man) corresponds to the amygdaleum superficiale and the periamygdaleum of Brockhaus' nomenclature. In this work the cortical amygdaloid nucleus has been studied with the criteria of the German writer in mind and the following considerations and secondary subdivisions have been made: superficially, the periamygdaleum is composed of portions of the second cortical layer and contains small and very numerous deeply stained pyramidal neurons. These layers do not present a continuity as in the cortex and they can be divided into (1) an oral part with dorsal (pAid, figs. 1-2) and ventral (pAov, figs. 1-2) divisions; (2) and intermediate part with dorsal (pAd, figs. 3-5) intermediate (pAi, figs. 3-5) and ventral (pAcv, fig. 6) divisions. The amygdaleum superficiale (Asf, figs. 1-6) is the representation of other cortical layer in the amygdala, but it cannot be subdivided, forming instead a heteregeneous portion with no specific cellular composition. Morphologically, this portion forms a large layer medial to the basolateral group, and has two poles (caudal and oral) and intermediate portion. Dorsal and ventral parts are distinguishable in each of these subdivisions. All these structures are shown in the accompanying reconstruction and together form the cortical nucleus of previous writers." (p. 520)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "Basal amygdaloid nucleus. …The pars lateralis (API, figs. 1-6) can be divided into magnocellular, mediocellular and parvocellular parts. The magnocellular part (mac, figs. 2-6) occupies a dorsal position. This part has two distinct subdivisions: the ventral subdivision (macv, fig. 4) is continuus with the remaining portion of the pars lateralis of the basal nucleus and presents a dorsomedial prolongation (macdm, fig. 4). The dorsal subdivision forms an independent mass of cells (macdl, fig. 4) dorsal to the lateral nucleus. …Ventrally, the mediocellular (mec, fig. 2-6) portion is formed by paler, smaller and sparser cells. The parvocellular portion (pc, figs. 2-6) is situated basally in the lateral part of the basal nucleus and between the mediocellular and the supragranular portions." (pp. 511, 514)
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: Area API is the lateral part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus and area APV the medial part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus.

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "The lateral amygdaloid nucleus has been recognized as one of the main divisions of the amygdala. Histologically, however, the lateral nucleus of the monkey can be shown to include 5 distinct portions: limitans, gracilicellularis, magnocellularis, mediocellularis and parvocellularis. Laterally, the lateral amygaloid nucleus is bounded by the external capsule. In its rostral half the dorsolateral part of the lateral nucleus is broken into by fiber bundles of the stria terminalis passing forward to the anterior commissure. This portion of the lateral nucleus has a special aspect and forms the limitans portion (li, figs. 2-5). …The gracilicellularis (gc, figs. 2-3) forms a dorsomedial prolongation situated in the anterior half of the lateral nucleus, between the magnocellularis of the basal nucleus ventrally, the oralis portion of the amygdaloid anterior area dorsally and the accessory basal nucleus medially. …The remaining chief nuclear mass of the lateral nucleus is divisible into a dorsal magnocellular portion (mac, figs. 2-6) situated ventral to the limitans portion and distinguishable from the other parts of the lateral nucleus by the denser arrangements of its neurons. There is also an intermediate mediocellular portion (med, figs. 2-6) and a ventral parvocellular portion (pc, figs. 2-5)." (p. 508, 511)

"(APM, figs 2-6). The accessory basal nucleus or amygdaleum profundum mediale of Brockhaus has an oval shape. The cephalic pole lies in intimate relation with the cortical amygdaloid nucleus. Its caudal tip appears caudal to the posterior poles of the basal and lateral nuclei. Previous writers have made a subdivision of the accessory basal nucleus into medial and lateral portions. In the present reconstructive study and according to the cellular disposition 4 portions can be recognized in the accessory basal nucleus of the monkey: partes magnocellularis, mediocellularis, densocellularis and mixtocellularis. A secondary subdivision of the magnocellular portion into a lateral and medial part is evident. The pars magnocellularis lateralis (macl, figs. 4-6) is located laterodorsal within the accessory basal nucleus laterally, contains the largest neurons of this nucleus, and appears homogeneous and deeply stained. The pars magnocellularis medialis (macm, figs. 2-6) has a medial situation within the accessory nucleus.It contains an intermingling of small and large neurons. These nuclei are in relation with the pars magnocellularis lateralis, the mediocellularis and the densocellularis. The mediocellular portion (mec, figs. 2-6) is located between both magnocellular portions and is very similar histologically to the medial portion but can be recognized because its cellular density is poorer. Thepars mixtocellularis (mic, figs. 4-6) occupies a ventrocaudal situation in the accessory nucleus containing small and medium sized cells, with a preponderance of granular neurons.The densocellular portion (dc, figs. 4-5) is a small rounded mass that appears in the accessory nucleus between the medial magnocellular and the mediocellular portions, in the medial third of the longitudinal axis of this nucleus." (p. 518)

A secondary subdivision of the magnocellular portion into a lateral and medial part is evident. The pars magnocellularis lateralis (macl, figs. 4-6) is located laterodorsal within the accessory basal nucleus laterally, contains the largest neurons of this nucleus, and appears homogeneous and deeply stained. The pars magnocellularis medialis (macm, figs. 2-6) has a medial situation within the accessory nucleus.It contains an intermingling of small and large neurons. These nuclei are in relation with the pars magnocellularis lateralis, the mediocellularis and the densocellularis. The mediocellular portion (mec, figs. 2-6) is located between both magnocellular portions and is very similar histologically to the medial portion but can be recognized because its cellular density is poorer. Thepars mixtocellularis (mic, figs. 4-6) occupies a ventrocaudal situation in the accessory nucleus containing small and medium sized cells, with a preponderance of granular neurons.The densocellular portion (dc, figs. 4-5) is a small rounded mass that appears in the accessory nucleus between the medial magnocellular and the mediocellular portions, in the medial third of the longitudinal axis of this nucleus." (p. 518)

"The pars medialis (APV, figs. 1-6) is situated ventromedial to the pars lateralis. It can be divided into pyramidal, granular, supragranular, and glomerular portions. The pyramidal portion (py, figs. 2-6) is situated between the corticoamygdaloid transition area medially, the pars lateralis of the basal nucleus laterally, and the accessory basal nucleus dorsally. It is narrow in its rostral pole and wider in the caudal tip. It contains small and middle sized neurons and a few pyramidal cells. The granularis (gr, figs. 2-5) forms a narrow portion situated between the pyramidalis and the supragranularis. It contains intermingled small granular and medium sized cells. Both granularis and pyramidalis form the deep portion of the medial part of the basal nucleus of other authors. The supragranularis (sgr, fig. 2-6) corresponds to the superficial part of Lauer and consists of a gray band which merges laterally with the lateral nucleus and medially with the cortico-amygdaloid transition area or with the pyriform cortex. It is formed of small, deeply stained granular cells. The glomerular portion forms several independent small masses (gl, fig. 6) and a large mass situated between the lateral nucleus and the ventricle (gl, fig. 4)." (pp. 514, 518)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "The cortical nucleus described by Lauer ('45; monkey) and Crosby and Humphrey ('41; man) corresponds to the amygdaleum superficiale and the periamygdaleum of Brockhaus' nomenclature. In this work the cortical amygdaloid nucleus has been studied with the criteria of the German writer in mind and the following considerations and secondary subdivisions have been made: superficially, the periamygdaleum is composed of portions of the second cortical layer and contains small and very numerous deeply stained pyramidal neurons. These layers do not present a continuity as in the cortex and they can be divided into (1) an oral part with dorsal (pAid, figs. 1-2) and ventral (pAov, figs. 1-2) divisions; (2) and intermediate part with dorsal (pAd, figs. 3-5) intermediate (pAi, figs. 3-5) and ventral (pAcv, fig. 6) divisions. The amygdaleum superficiale (Asf, figs. 1-6) is the representation of other cortical layer in the amygdala, but it cannot be subdivided, forming instead a heteregeneous portion with no specific cellular composition. Morphologically, this portion forms a large layer medial to the basolateral group, and has two poles (caudal and oral) and intermediate portion. Dorsal and ventral parts are distinguishable in each of these subdivisions. All these structures are shown in the accompanying reconstruction and together form the cortical nucleus of previous writers." (p. 520)
